channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Citi's Moore Holding Steady on Stocks, Likes AI
item.description: "I would love to be in a place where I can say 'let's buy, it's time' but I just don't see it," Citi Wealth CIO Kate Moore says on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Yields Slide as Trump Tariff Threat Reignites Growth Concerns
item.description: Treasury yields declined Friday after President Donald Trump threatened new tariffs, reigniting concerns about damage to the US economy and sparking a stock-market selloff.
item.dc:creator: Liz Capo McCormick, Ye Xie

item.title: Meat Producer JBS Says US Listing Plan Approved by Minority Shareholders
item.description: JBS SA’s minority shareholders approved a restructuring plan that clears the way for a long-awaited listing of the world’s largest meat producer in New York, even after fierce opposition from advocacy investors and environmental groups.
item.dc:creator: Clarice Couto

media:content.media:description: The JBS Beef Production Facility in Greeley, Colorado.

item.title: Tariff Pain Already Priced Into Stocks, Citi's Moore Says
item.description: "I don't think we're going to get past the point of (tariff) pain by the time we get to Labor Day," Citi Wealth CIO Kate Moore says on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Fall as Trade Jitters Spur Flight to Bonds: Markets Wrap
item.description: Global markets were rattled by President Donald Trump’s threats to impose aggressive tariffs on the European Union and Apple Inc., with stocks getting hit, the dollar sliding toward its lowest since 2023 and bonds joining gains in haven assets.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

media:content.media:description: Comprehensive cross-platform coverage of the U.S. market close on Bloomberg Television, Bloomberg Radio, and YouTube with Romaine Bostick, Scarlet Fu, Carol Massar and Tim Stenovec.

item.title: US Long-Term Borrowing Costs Surge Over Deficit Concerns
item.description: Bond investors are demanding more and more compensation to hold long-dated US debt as global markets grow anxious about the widening fiscal deficit in the world’s biggest economy.
item.dc:creator: Aline Oyamada, Alice Gledhill

item.title: Thames Faces Renewed Bonus Scrutiny as It Races to Fix Finances
item.description: Thames Water’s expenditure has come under fresh scrutiny from a group of UK lawmakers, as the beleaguered utility rushes to sort out its finances.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: A Thames Water sewage warning sign on a road in the UK. Photographer: Carlos Jasso/Bloomberg

item.title: US Stocks Slide as Trump Threatens Apple, EU With Tariffs
item.description: Wall Street’s mood soured on Friday morning as threats from President Donald Trump put investors into risk-off mode.
item.dc:creator: Joel Leon

media:content.media:description: A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 15, 2025. US stocks were on pace to snap a three-day winning streak Thursday, driven by declines in technology, energy and retailers as traders assessed a slew of mixed economic figures.

item.title: RBI to Make a Record Transfer of $32 Billion to Government
item.description: India’s central bank will give a record dividend to the government, shoring up finances to bolster growth in Asia’s third largest economy.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: A Reserve Bank of India branch in Prayagraj, Uttar Pradesh, India. Photographer: PV/YT/Bloomberg

item.title: CoreWeave Bulls Face Off Against Short Sellers as Shares Spike
item.description: CoreWeave Inc. shares have been on a tear as investors snap up the stock despite widespread concerns about elevated debt levels, the rate of cash-burn and the long-term demand for the cloud-computing services it provides.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke, Jeran Wittenstein

media:content.media:description: CoreWeave signage in Times Square in New York.

item.title: Canada Retail Sales Rose Again in April Despite Tariff War
item.description: Canadian consumers kept on spending last month, defying a tariff war that threatens their employment and wealth.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Hoodies in a souvenir store in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on Tuesday, April 29, 2025. US President Donald Trumps threats have spurred many Canadians to band together in response, touting national unity and boycotting American products.

item.title: Heir to $27 Billion Bharti Fortune Joins Britain’s Wealth Exodus
item.description: An heir from one of India’s richest families, the top shareholder in UK telecommunications giant BT Group Plc, has relocated from Britain amid tax hikes on the nation’s wealthy residents.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Stupples, Max Harlow

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers on the skyline of the Square Mile financial district of the City of London, UK, on Thursday, Jan. 9, 2025. The pound dropped to a more than one-year low, stocks fell and gilts extended a fourth day of losses on concern the Labour government will struggle to keep the deficit in check as borrowing costs surge. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: Congo Lifts Ex-President Kabila’s Immunity From Prosecution
item.description: Democratic Republic of Congo’s Senate lifted former President Joseph Kabila’s immunity from prosecution amid allegations he’s supporting an armed rebellion in the east of the country.
item.dc:creator: Michael J Kavanagh

item.title: Bitcoin Options Show Bulls Unbowed With Open Interest at Record
item.description: Even though Bitcoin has retreated from record territory, options show that traders remain extremely bullish with open interest reaching an all-time high.
item.dc:creator: Sidhartha Shukla

item.title: Inside the World of Royal Finances
item.description: Brits should be told how much their royals’ extravagant lifestyles are costing them, says Bloomberg Opinion columnist Rosa Prince. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: UK Stocks Slump as Trump Trade War Concerns Reignite
US Inflation, Recession Forecasts Ease on Trade Truce With China
item.description: Latest Bloomberg survey still suggests economy is shifting into a lower gear
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva, Dana Morgan

item.title: EU Eyes Nord Stream 2 Sanctions to Stamp Out Russian Gas Return
item.description: The European Union is nearing a decision to include the Nord Stream 2 gas pipelines linking Germany and Russia in a fresh proposal of sanctions against Moscow amid persistent rumors about reviving flows that the bloc wants to stop.
item.dc:creator: Ewa Krukowska, Alberto Nardelli, Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: A gas receiving compressor station of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: Gold Climbs After Trump’s EU and Apple Threats Stoke Trade Fears
item.description: Gold extended its weekly gain toward 5%, after Donald Trump threatened to impose sweeping tariffs on the European Union and Apple Inc., fueling demand for haven assets.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: An employee arranges gold bars at the Italpreziosi SpA precious metals refinery plant in Arezzo, Italy, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. Gold fell, snapping a two-day advance, as signs of progress on US-China trade talks curbed demand for havens even as military hostilities between India and Pakistan escalated.

item.title: Europeans Plan Fewer Summer US Trips as Trump Backlash Grows
item.description: Europeans are planning 10% fewer trips to the US as the busy summer season approaches, in the latest sign that some international travelers are avoiding America as backlash grows against President Donald Trump’s policies.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Palazzo

media:content.media:description: Tourists ride the Staten Island Ferry in New York City.

item.title: Senate Expected to Change Trump's Tax Bill
item.description: The US Senate plans to make time-consuming revisions to President Donald Trump's tax and spending package, which includes increasing the US debt limit. Bloomberg's Tyler Kendall reports from Washington. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: European Bonds Rally as Trump Tariff Threat Fuels Rate-Cut Bets
item.description: European bonds rallied after US President Donald Trump threatened to apply levies of 50% on the region starting June 1, fueling bets policymakers will have to lower interest rates further to support the economy.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie

item.title: 25% Tariffs on Apple If iPhones Not US-Made, Trump Says
item.description: President Donald Trump threatened Apple Inc. with a tariff of at least 25% if the tech company does not manufacture iPhones in the US. Bloomberg's Tyler Kendall reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Barclays Advises Switch to Nigeria Shorter-Dated Dollar Bonds
item.description: Barclays is recommending investors shift away from Nigeria’s longer-dated dollar bonds, noting that yields in the mid-section of the curve now look more attractive.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Osae-Brown

media:content.media:description: Nnamdi Azikwe Street by Idumota market in Lagos, Nigeria.

item.title: Trump Recommends 50% Tariff on EU From June 1
item.description: President Donald Trump threatened a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union starting on June 1, saying “our discussions with them are going nowhere.” He made the comments in a Truth Social post on Friday, criticizing what he said were the trade bloc’s “powerful Trade Barriers.” Jonathan Ferro and Lisa Abramowicz report.

item.title: Oil Extends Weekly Slump as Trump Floats 50% Tariff on the EU
item.description: Oil extended this week’s decline after US President Donald Trump threatened to slap a 50% tariff on the European Union.
item.dc:creator: Paul Burkhardt, Yongchang Chin

media:content.media:description: The Deer Park Complex oil refinery and petrochemical plant, owned by Petroleos Mexicanos (PEMEX), in Houston, Texas, US, on Saturday, March 8, 2025. Some 40% of the crude oil processed at US refineries is imported, and Canada and Mexico, the No. 1 and No. 2 foreign suppliers of oil to the US, respectively, together deliver more than two-thirds of that oil. Photographer: Mark Felix/Bloomberg

item.title: Rand Shrugs Off Trump and Budget to End Week on a Positive Note
item.description: A week that started fraught with risks for the rand is ending on a positive note for the South African currency.
item.dc:creator: Mpho Hlakudi

media:content.media:description: Street vendors at an outdoor market in the Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana’s third attempt to deliver a budget represents his sternest test yet.

item.title: Stocks Muted as Treasuries Pressure Ease; Harvard's Foreign Student Ban | Bloomberg Brief 05/23/2025
item.description: US equity futures hover and pressure eases on US Treasury yields after soaring on concerns over the outlook for US deficits as investors head into Memorial Day weekend. The US bans Harvard University from having foreign students amid tensions between the administration and the college. Marvin Barth of Thematic Markets says the bond market has sent Trump, Congress and Americans a warning regarding the deficit. Sitara Sundar says she expects decent upside in some sectors within tech. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: ECB’s Lane Says US Price Jump Wouldn’t Necessarily Reach Europe
item.description: Faster US inflation triggered by President Donald Trump’s tariffs wouldn’t necessarily spill over into the euro zone, according to European Central Bank Chief Economist Philip Lane.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

media:content.media:description: Philip Lane, chief economist of the European Central Bank (ECB), during an interview in London, UK, on Tuesday, Nov. 26, 2024. ECB officials across the hawk-dove spectrum have signaled further interest-rate cuts after the fourth quarter-point reduction of the year last week.

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: UK Stocks Slump as Trump Rattles Market With 50% EU Tariff Threat
